Name: A Shiver of Light (A Merry Gentry Novel)

ReviewList.Text: I've been a diehard fan from Laurell Hamilton's first book.  With the ridiculously long time since her last Merry Gentry  book I was really expecting something grand, but I must say I've never been more disappointed in a book. It's like she's lost interest in giving us those amazing books she started out with. Not only this series but also the Anita Blake series. The last three or four Anita books have almost been painful to just finish it.  I don't mind pay top dollar for a quality book and I've been doing it for years, but Laurell Hamilton's books are no longer top quality.

It's sad, but I'm mourning the end of a once pretty good series, written by someone who USED to be able to put a decently imaginative story together with characters we liked and cared about (that had an actual plot instead of massive info dumps where everything "good" happens off screen) In Shiver, we are treated to endless descriptions of what everybody's wearing and how it matches their eyes, hair, etc, to the point of tediousness. Lots of continuity errors and too much rehashing of exactly what everybody looks like, too much tell and not enough show, no story, no plot, just random bits of info dumping at strategic places that tries to disguise itself as a plot. The author also directly went against things she had already established in the previous books that made no sense. I did re-read the the whole series in the past few weeks prior... and this mess is nowhere close to the caliber of writing that she was once capable of producing. It honestly would have been lovely to be re-captured by the magic Hamilton had in the early days of her writing. Bummed, as those days are no more and we can now say that it's over for both of this author's series.

I remember a high school English teacher telling us you had a very poorly written story if you had to killing off a character just to create an ending. Seriously how do you wrap a book by telling the readers about the climax of the story that took place off scene?

Here's the thing.  I NEVER write reviews.  This book though has me so angry, annoyed & feeling disrespected by LKH, that I had to write one this time.  I believe loyalty should be rewarded not punished.  I have stuck with LKH through the long waits in between books.  I have bought the next book in one of her series even after I questioned why a story was going off the rails.  I had hoped that the long wait for this latest next chapter into  Merry's story meant that I would be reading a thoroughly epic adventure in revenge, redemption & righting of wrongs.  Instead I was subjected to a mind numbing expose on the power of love.  Never mind the obvious problems with continuity of the eight books that came before or the repetitive editorial on fashion for fairies & fey. What little drama there was, was not only glossed over but treated with trite quips of overcoming brutal trauma with hard work & a few psych conversations.  Other reviews before mine have pretty much covered the multitude of what is wrong with this book.  So I won't repeat it all.  We get enough of that every time someone walks by Merry's line of sight.  The lack of plot, the disrespect & unbelievable lack of legitimate dealing with sexual trauma, an out of nowhere death of a major character at the slap dash ending all left me feeling punished for sticking with this character & her story.  No where in this book is the strong, tough "ruthless"  heroine that we have come to know.  And if she is gone, well then so am I.

I had stopped reading the Anita Blake series years ago, but I still enjoyed the Merry Gentry books. Not anymore! The character list includes a healer who magically heals up Merry's lover Frost after he gets severely wounded, but instead of healing Merry's magic hooha after childbirth, LKH instead let's the readers enjoy PAGES of inane dialogue of her wishing there was a way for her to bang her guys again.  The sex scenes are full of Merry screaming her pleasures into skin, screaming pleasures around the thick shaft of one of her men, rolling her eyes up to look at someone as she screams pleasures, screaming etc... Yes we know Merry and auntie hate each other, but go ahead and fill 10-15 pages of witty passive aggressive banter between the two of them so we can all be reminded of that fact, and have this same conversation repeated a couple more times throughout the book in case we missed it the first time.  Ugh. Just ugh. Save your money and Wikipedia the storyline to see what happens. I would say LKH should know better, but I think she genuinely sees nothing wrong with her writing and taking a crap on these characters I used to love.

It's been five years since the last book published and I was so excited unfortunately it was not worth the wait. I don't understand how she can have so many good storylines ideas and instead of developing them she fills the entire book on stupid stupid dialogue. I don't want to hear about money  problems they don't solve, what the men look like. There's been six books before this one we know what the men look like give a brief description move on and get to the action. I want to see the action not a build-up then a one sentence climax. Instead of the action it's pages and pages of her crying and then her men comforting her then we get pages of her talking about what the babies look like and then worry about the babies and then more crying. I think we should call the book instead of A Shiver of Light but Shaking and Crying (A Merry Gentry Hysteria Novel) .

I have waited years for another installment in this series and was can only that I wish the series had ended with the last book.  Much of the book was repetitive, although the play on inter-personal relationships was nice, I don't appreciate her pulling such a startling ending in the last few chapters with very little build up or going against her previous books, why is there now suddenly a third baby?  Too many inconsistencies between her books and a complete let down, if you liked this series pretend this book doesn't exist.

This was bad. So bad that I couldn't even finish it, despite my obsession with knowing which baby belonged to which yummy man. After wading through the pages of repetitive descriptions of each character , (Yes, we get it... Long beautiful hair, tri-colored eyes-a-plenty...fairies are pretty.  We're not morons) and the endless slush of rehashed story lines and synapses, I just couldn't take any more of the repetitive drivel. This book had very little new content, or new story line or plot, and frankly, I think she wrote it for someone who'd never read a book in this series because you could read this one and be completely caught up. I mean, she even managed to reference two old boyfriends and the Jack-In-Irons from the first books! This book was an insult to die hard fans of this series, and I can't believe I waited two years for this literary equivalent of dung. And I thought Anita Blake had gone to the dogs...well, here comes Merry right behind her! I'm returning it. I'm done with Ms. Hamilton, and her lazy writing.

I want to preface this by saying I'm a huge fan of LKH.  My first book I ever read was an Anita Blake book Incubus Dreams and I loved it. I loved the sex, I loved the men, and I loved the writing. I've read every book she's ever written and when others complained I didn't because I enjoyed it. I did t enjoy this book.  I truly hope that she reads some of these reviews and sees that even her die hard fans are disappointed. I'm used to her writing style, I know her books has a lot of talking and descriptions of clothes and hair and again I'm fine with that but something has to happen In a book to make it interesting. She repeated things so many times in this book it was ridiculous. If I hear "where is my Darkness? Bring me my Darkness." One more time I might vomit. Over and over she repeated things we all know. Again the same conversations the characters have had over and over. It was very underwhelming.  Also this might be gross but Merry just gave birth and she can't have sex but she can do other things sexually with her men, well I dont know about other woman but after having my children I was bleeding like a stuck pig for a while, not a very sexy feeling. I'm sorry that's all I could think of during the sex scenes. They also were repetitive and boring. I gave it 2 stars because there was potential. Talk of Holly and Ash challenging the Goblin King, the King plotting against Merry, The Queen wanting to see the babies.  But no all we got was talk,talk,talk repeating things over and over,frown,talk and more talk. Anything that was remotely interesting happened off screen. Also what's the point of all the dogs? Are they house broken? Do they shed? And lastly has anyone noticed that Galen is becoming Nathaniel? Obviously Merry is Anita and Rhys is Asher.  As another reviewer wrote LKH has to do better then this, we her readers deserve better and so do her characters.

I am completely disappointed in LKH. With 5 years between this novel and the last, I expected better. There was almost no action in this novel. BTW, we get it LKH. Your fantasy is oral. Can we move on now? Merry has been turned into a week-willed "messiah" . . . I felt like all she did was whine or cry. Plus, there are editorial and continuity mistakes. Is Merry immortal or not? She was in the previous book.

I'm very disappointed about this book. I have all of ms. Hamilton's books and I have always been a big fan. I have recommented both her Anited blake novels and her merry gentry series to friends and even my book club. But after reading shiver of light, I'll have to rethink about buying anymore of her books.  There  was barely a story line, most of the book just kept going on about want the character's clothing. I understand that it is important to bring thecharactors to life, but to spend so much time on just describing what each one is wearing is ridiculous.  Then this whole disney theme started happening. Every solution to any serious problem or question was answer with love will solve everything. I know that there should be an element of romance to keep the story intersting, but they spent half the book just telling each other "I love you",and  reasuring merry that she is the most desirable and greatest woman there is, that all the other sidhe barely gets a mention.  Then the climex of the book is barely two charters, with one of the most important player just dying and the villian not barely getting punish. I have to say, this is the most disappointing book I have ever read, especially by one of my favor authors.

The ending sucked. Not just a little but huge gasping supersonic black whole sucked! I might have given the book three stars for the effort after 2 years of waiting.  But Hamilton committed an unpardonable sin. She misread Merry's fans so badly as to think it was okay to kill off one of the main characters, again!  One I liked. (As opposed to one of those who continues to whine all the time).  Authors think they own the characters they write about.  WRONG.  After a character grabs hold in a series the readers EXPECT them to survive all, be at risk, get injured, be near death, perhaps. But never do any of us appreciate it when an author kills one off. Especially as an adjunct to such senseless dribble as was passed off at the end of this last installment. Not to mention the tidy brief (very brief) ending that followed.  No more.  Hamilton has ticked me off, wasted my time, gotten my hard earned money for the last time.  I mean Really! Doesn't she even remember her own back story! Merry was chosen by the Goddess. Has GROWN in power and was no longer believed to be mortal.  If Hamilton really hates writing this series so much that she's mucked it up this bad, she should just stop. GO. Retire somewhere, spend her money and leave her readers the he** alone to imagine their own ending.  There is enough grief in REAL life without putting up with this. I expected miracles from Merry, not weak resignation and story regression with some false illusion of a cheerful future. Hah, maybe Taranis helped write this one.

I used to adore this series...and I am so sad that LKH has lost her way so profoundly. I spent the entire book waiting for something (anything) to happen. The book is filled with long conversations that lead to.....more long conversations that lead to...nowhere! The tedious conversations were broken up by exhausting and repetitive descriptions of the eyes and hair of each character. I can only hope that LKH will find her way back from the land of blah before all of her fans lose patience and stop caring.

Honestly, I don't know if I'll be able to finish this "book."  I am at 75% into it on my Kindle, and there has been absolutely NO action. Each chapter turns into the next chapter, with the same details infodumping/bizarre phrasing that we have already seen in each proceeding chapter, nay! each BOOK that LKH has ever written. Who told her that using the same bizarre and awkward phrasing everytime an event is even mentioned is ok? I understand that repetition can be a writing tool, but even I, a non-writer, know that she's just not using this technique correctly. If I have to read one more description of the hairstyle, clothing, eye color, etc., of a character EVERY SINGLE TIME he/she enters the picture, well I will .... just keep reading, I guess, out of this terrifying morbid fascination I have with all LKH books. But, I didn't need to finish the book to know that this "novel" is a train wreck beyond salvation. Save your money, folks. It's just not worth it.

Sadly, this latest and most anticipated entry into the MG series is both overpriced and overrated. As a follower and reader of all LKH's books, I feel cheated. SoL has absolutely no plot, character development, originality (repetitive descriptions and phrases throughout the book and previous books, including the AB series), or anything remotely resembling a progression in the story. All of the real action/excitement occurs off page! Turn the page, be "told" something major has happened in a sentence or, if lucky, a  paragraph, move on like it's no big deal, and that's it. My wallet is lighter and I feel cheated. If you absolutely must read this book because you love the series, I suggest checking it out from the library and saving your money for an author who actually gives a s#&t; about her characters, craft, and readers.
Way too much filler (that we have already read, over and over and over...) and not nearly enough story.  I may have to pretend that this book just doesn't exist.

What did I like about this book, not a single solitary thing because the author once again demonstrates her loss of talent and the contempt she must have for her fans to have put out such a literary travesty!!! Apparently she was not satisfied with ruining The Anita Blake character and series her last 2 books of the Merry Gentry series accomplishes boredom, repetition of old information to fill pages, the destruction of main characters images, killing a main character that was both exciting and well loved by the few fans she had left. This book was my last hope for this author and it failed miserably. Laurell K. Hamilton is single handedly killing her own career and dragging her agent, editors and publishing house along with her since they are also responsible for publishing such trite. I was a real fan of Anita Blake as well as Merry Gentry Novels and was fully invested in all the many characters of this once wonderful and of fictional literature that I feel opened so many doors to the urban paranormal and fantasy genres. The heroines and heroes were both heroic and worth admiring and loving. The romance was lovely and had a wow factor now and for a long time all this authors work is about pain and depravity. This is surely a very public and published meltdown!  Funny that this book has therapy for so many of the abused characters hopefully the author is taking her own advice from her books. Meanwhile it saddens me to see the ruination of Anita Blake, Merry Gentry and all the many characters that became so real and loved by so many of us readers. I know that is why I bought this book and why I believe so many of us continued to stick by this author until I read this book that is. This is the end for me the decimation of Doyle's and Frost's characters in the same way in which she had done with almost all the male characters of Anita Blake's finally convinced me to be done with this authors work completely. The killing of one of my favorite characters that showed so much more promise of action, excitement and romance and sentiment was unforgivable!!! Only to be left with characters that she could have chosen to eliminate which are outright boring and just plain wrong in so many ways shows  that this authors no longer has what it takes and hasn't had it for quite a long time!!! I will never buy another Laurell K. Hamilton book again!!!  Save your time and money as I intend to do for Patricia Briggs, Mercy Thompson series, Ilona Andrews, Kate Daniels series, Cassandra Claire's, Mortal Instruments series, Rachel Caine's, Morganville Vampires series, Susan Ee's Penryn and the End of Days series. I am an avid reader of fantasy and science fiction so these are just a few of my favorites. I was being generous giving A Shiver of Light a 1 star this book deserved so much less!!!

Based on the last few Anita books, I made an educated guess that I did not want to purchase this book.  But I was curious and picked it up at the library.  Ugh!  I read it but was bored.  It was so repetitive and lacking in plot that I found myself putting it down often.  I don't think I will even bother to borrow books by LKH anymore.  But I may reread the first few in each series again that I have on my shelf.  Take a lesson from some of the cable TV shows lately and conclude the story before you drive it into the ground.

This was so bad that I ended up skimming most of it. So bad that it makes me wonder who the publisher is paying to write 5-star reviews. There was no real plotline - just lots of people talking. Most of the book is Merry complaining or crying, or other people telling her how great she is. The sex scenes are infrequent (2 or 3?), and boring. The few major plot events that happen occur "off screen" or are treated only shallowly. Like other reviewers, I wondered if the author had actually re-read her other books before writing this, because many individuals act out of character. Magical facts established in earlier books (i.e., that Merry isn't really mortal anymore; that the Goddess won't be blessing the fey who don't appreciate her) are completely ignored. Yet, much of the language is quite clearly copied directly from earlier books, so the author must have at least searched through the text files for things to re-use. It's really inexcusably bad.

Terrible. I'm so tired of hearing detailed descriptions of what everyone looks like!!  Yes Merry...you have red hair. Doyle's is black, Frost's is white..blah blah.  That's half the book. The other half is explaining what happened in previous books. The end.

I'm a die hard fan of Laurell Hamilton but this book was, in my opinion, not worth what I paid for it. I stuck it out through the book but it was hard to do. So many of the same phrases were used over and over. Then it was a recap on the whole issue of Merry being mortal and her blood making the immortals mortal that I literally started skipping paragraphs. I thought this issue had already been resolved? I also understand that something bad ALWAYS has to happen so I was expecting her aunt or uncle to do something to hurt her. But for Laurell to spend 90% of the book talking about love being so important to Merry I never would have seen that it all lead to her losing one of her children's fathers. And for the character to die due to a gun shot would that was minor compared to some of the injuries that her men have recovered from in the past sort of ticked me off. But the fact that it was Sholto that was murdered so easily when he is supposed to be one of the most powerful, and one of my personal favorites, finished me off. I won't be reading anymore of her books in this particular series. Hopefully the next book in the Anita Blake series won't put me off that one as well. Sorry Ms. Hamilton, but maybe you should have let the Merry series end with the previous book.

I'm a diehard LKH fan, and have read both the Meredith Gentry and Anita Blake series with gusto. Until now. If I'd read this book first, I would NEVER have picked up another LKH novel. Talking, thinking, feeling. No action until nearly the end, and what happens isn't consistent with previous events and established precedents. This book was phoned in. DON'T BOTHER

I read the reviews and hoped they were wrong. No such luck. LKH has been getting less and less satisfying for the longest time. I quit reading the Anita Blake Series when i changed from a supernatural crime series with sex thrown in to a harem story with some crime thrown in (barely). At least the Merry Gentry series had a good reason for the sex. But this book was 65% descriptions, 20% sex, 10% flashbacks and 5% story. I had high hopes for this book since so many interesting things were supposed to happen. Taranis dethroned, Andais faced down, and the children finally appear.But all of those things were barely a facet of the story. Taranis, the big bad of the story apparently fades quietly offstage just because his hand is hurt, rather than fighting for  the throne he has held for THOUSANDS of years. Andais is suicidal but "snaps out of her insanity" when Meredith doesn't kill her, because that happens.  The children are ridiculously powerful already of course, though the only boy is less powerful than his sisters as any neofeminist supernatural erotic story must have it. Basically, i'm disappointed. But i'm especially disappointed with how Sholto dies. A single shot that he never even sees, and no mention of bringing him back is made. Even though the whole resurrection thing has happened for others already. Is it because Merry is only Queen because he is King and now she gets to have a crown to rule on her own? Is it because he's no longer interesting at all since his neutering was made complete? Whatever the reason for that or any of this disappointing book, i'm done with this series. I'm tired of being disappointed by LKH and wasting time i could be spending on finding new and interesting authors.

The book was so below my expectations. It did not read like Merry at all, there was no main plot to the story and it was just about a waste of time to read. merry was whiny and emotional and the book was so repetative about previous content that it was nearly painful to read. Even the sex scenes were diappointing and nearly absent. I had such high hopes for one of my favorite series and i was so disappointed. Perhaps Hamilton waited too long to continue the story that she was no longer part of it. It would have been better if it had never been written, or at least completely re-written to be much more effective.

.......oh Mrs. Hamilton, you completely forgot who your characters are and what they have already accomplished. I would have rather you ended at the last book then have us wait 5 years for this dreadful piece of work. This book basically went over everything we already knew from the past books and i am not quite sure if it was for new readers or what but for those of us who have been reading this series since it started i am utterly irritated, perhaps you should have actually reread your own literature...disappointed will be an understatement. Please do not even finish this series if this is your direction. I have noticed this trend you have going on, first with Anita Blake and now Merry, it's as if you stopped caring about these two strong women and basically just made them sex objects, no longer do we get great dialogue and awesome fight scenes, now our girls are weak and for some reason they NEED the sex to even live instead of just to get it on when the need strikes with their man/men...blah

After waiting 4yrs, this is what we got? It seems Laurell Hamiton was hitting the wine a little too much. Conversations were literally repeated through the book and she wrote what Merry's "favoritest" place is:/ Did the editor even glance at the book, or were they I imbibing with Laurell? Honestly I thought this book could be a drinking game. Have a shot every time someone says, "What do you mean?" or "I don't understand?" Double shot when Merry says it. I've read every book and that is why I hung in there, but if she's lost her desire to write then just stop. Don't give us this slop. Seriously, 5 pages spent describing and inexplicable crying jag. Less effort was used with one of her lover's murder. God I hope she's embarrassed for releasing this tripe:(

I waited 5 years for this book and it was awful. I had to read the line "then the Queen would say where is my Darkness bring me my Darkness, and some one would die" multiple times throughout this book. I skipped more than 30 pages total  of her descriptions of clothing, eyes, and hair color of every person in the book. After a while it ceases to paint a picture and just becomes tedious.  It seems that Ms Hamilton spends all of her time and energy writing the Anita Blake series ( and let's be honest, it is clearly a fictional outlet for her to write about her polyamory lifestyle, who cares ?) this book is an affront to the fans that have waited so long to read it. It would have been better to have not written anything rather than dial it in. This was a waste of my time and money.

I swear if my ear's could of jump of my head  they would have. Never have I read so much about nothing, and the endless chatter on and on about this height, and this persons eye color and how short Merry was it was endless. Drinking didn't make it better. I will never buy another one in the series or Anita's, ever! I will never get back the time I have just wasted.
90% of this book is wasted words. Adjectives just to fill space and repeating the same sentences and phrases over and over. There was no substance to the book. It was horrible!!

Does the author think that the reader can't remember whatever it is she is explaining repeative once again for the fourth time? I've read all of Ms. Hamilton's books and it saddens me to realize that each book she has written in the past few years has become pages of the same dialogue repeated throughout the book. I kept reading, waiting to get past the explanations an author usually makes to explain for someone who might be new to the storyline but I never was able to find an actual story. "We loved him. He loved us. I loved Frost. Frost loved me." And yes, Doyle was known as the Queen's Darkness and yes Frost was her Killing Frost and yes Merry was raped by Taranis but I only need to read this part of the story once maybe twice not every chapter. This entire story was basically a re-hash of all the previous books and it was only in the last chapter anything new actually happened with the death of a main character and a resolution of the problem with King Taranis and then a list of how every other problem was solved. The End. Very disappointed in this book. I believe this will be the last time I spend money on a book by this author which does make me sad as her earlier books were fabulous.

Actually I have a different phrase in mind for this book. All the years of waiting and this is what Hamilton gave us. Come on did no one on her team reread the previous books. Whenever a new issue of a series is due to be published I reread all of the books. The possible storylines my imagination came up with while waiting for this to be published were better then what the author finally gave us. Seriously, while there were some characters that killing off would add to the story taking out Sholto wasn't one of them. When it happened I had to make myself finish the little bit of the book that was left thinking that it would somehow redeem the book the time wasted reading about the same stuff chapter to chapter, the whining and crying of what used to be strong characters. Woe is me. Doomed to disappointment. Of course this doesn't mean that if another book in the series came out that I wouldn't purchase it. What can I say. I have an optmistic hope that an author that I have been a fan of since the very beginning will stop screwing around and get the stories back on track.

I love The vast majority of Laurell K's books. I did not love this one, it was a fight to read the whole thing in the hopes it would get even marginally better. So many plot holes, repetitive chapters which tell the same backstory three times or more, and no plot what so ever. This doesn't even count as a filler book it has so little coherency. The characters are becoming more one dimensional as they go rather than becoming more real, she needs to invest more energy into this project or call it quits before she completely ruins it.

I love this series, so this book was a horrible disappointment. Too much exposition, no plot, not enough character development, and a horrible ending that was so rushed it made me think the whole first part of the book was nothing but a set of the author's ramblings that never saw an editor. Then, after a whole lot of nothing happening, she got her page quota in and had to come up with an ending. Wish I could get the time spent reading this book back.

LKH used to be an exciting, interesting writer....used to be. Now there is little plot and a whole lot of talking...both in the Merry Gentry books and the Anita Blake series. It is very VERY annoying when any kind of action stops while everyone discusses yet again a single issue that could be resolved in a sentence or two but goes on for a complete chapter. you could lift out 2/3 of the chapters in this book and not miss a single bit of the true plot.

I waited 5 years for this book to come out and all I can say is that I am disappointed with it.The story line drags most of the book and stuff don't happen to the last 3 chapters so it feels very rushed for a book that is 400 pages

This book reads like fan fiction a 14-year-old would have written. Everyone is either in love with Merry or jealous of her and in the most random and unnecessary thread ever she can travel in dreams to help soldiers who have nails with her blood on them (god complex, much?). Nothing really happens other than babies being born. And when did Doyle and Frost fall in love with one another? I think the author is confusing her two book series.

I really wanted to love this book because I truly love the characters. I found myself, however, skipping through large, preachy parts of it. Hamilton has become so redundant that I will definitely hesitate before reading any future books.  You would think that after such a long hiatus of this storyline, she could have come up with a richer story.  I'm happy that Merry has the "blessing of the Goddess" but if one more rose petal fell, I was going to barf.  And the whole therapy thing is mentioned so often, it makes you wonder what the heck is going on in the author's life. We don't want to hear about that!  I like the wildness of the fairy world. The action and adventure of the Wild Hunt.  I don't give a fig for everyone's "issues". The death at the end was a shock, though not in a good way. More shocking was how quickly it was dealt with. Also, the whole postpartum crying binges were yawn worthy. I skipped over those as well, which really left me with nothing much to read. My advise to LKH would be for her to let some of her best fans read what she's written before it's close to being published and get some honest advice on what needs to be changed before it's too late. I got very little out of this book and it was not worth the price.

Is it just me or is Merry's voice turning ino Anita Blake'd more and more? Same old romance and a shocking ending kept me reading, but it felt more like a short novella than a full book and it's beginning to read so much like the Anita Blake series that it was hard to keep the vision of who Merry is in my head as I read.

Im done with the series. Totally disappointed with storyline. I am tired of authors killing of favorite characters to bring drama. I dont read these types of series for realism. The last book was good and in my mind i'll keep that as last book because at least it had all the characters I adored. Too many of my mainstream authors are taking the easy way out and just lilling people off. I think I will probably end my anita blake while im ahead and still enjoy the books. This is the first bad review ive written and I hope its my last. Knowing the probability of other major characters dying off due to plot im recommending to my book buds not to buy. Ironically i could have been emotionally invested in this book but every time other stuff either wasnt written or abruptly ended.It was a waste of 13$.

This is the first review that I have written on Amazon. I don't usually write reviews but I had to say something after reading A Shiver of Light. This is what we waited 5 years for?? Either LKH simply doesn't care anymore (one could question if she ever did actually care about Merry) or she has truly lost what talent she may have had when she started the series. I gave up on Anita Blake many books ago, but I am now done.

I have read all of Laurel's books and they keep getting worse. I counted 4 times reading that the Red Caps ere between 7 and 13 feet tall. Really?? I think reading it once was enough. There was no plot and the main story started at 90% at the end and then just stopped. Not to mention for having newborn triplets she found time to have sex with 2 guys. Come on not realistic.  I could have forgiven that if there was actually a story behind this book. I really wish I could return this sorry excuse for a book. Luckily I didn't have to use my own money but it was part of the settlement about books being to much. Really this kindle book cost way to much. Yuck. Disappointment.

After waiting so long for a continuation of the Merry story this book was an utter let down. Not only was the bulk of the conversational backstory whine-tastic, I had to reread the ending a few times to make sure i wasn't missing PAGES of story because the main solution for a lot of merry's problems came 1) offstage and 2) out of thin air based on something "she remembered". UGH. Terrible. I had high hopes for LKH, now dashed. Goodbye Merry series.

I really think that it is time for Laurell to take down all of her sticky notes, wash out the tea mugs, clear out her office and lock it up and say goodbye to both this and the Anita Blake series. To simply say that they display some of the worse writing imaginable is too kind.

Overall, a very disappointing read.  All of the action occurs in the last few pages and isn't even described as it happens, but merely recapped. One word to describe this book would be lazy.  I was hoping LKH was just getting tired of writing Anita Blake and started to slip... well she went and ruined Mary as well. Awful story and writing. I love Hamilton's books.  This one sucked.  The entire plot happens in the last 20 pages - and I found that lacking as well.  I'm fairly certain I've read everything she's ever printed - and usually they're amazing, but this was just bad.  Some of the Anita Blake books have lacked the crime aspect to fit in the social changes, but I've never seen anything like this.

If Hamilton put half as much effort into creating an actual storyline or doing justice to major events as she does to her constant inane description of clothing, this might have been a somewhat decent book. There are pages of meaningless description that add absolutely nothing, and almost all opportunities to flesh out an action scene or pull genuine emotion (there was one decent emotional scene with Aisling) from a character (or the reader) were squandered. The couple of small love scenes felt mostly forced and uninspired, and what should have been a majorly emotional and heartrending scene was completely anticlimactic and a total disservice to a great character. This just seemed so stitched together and the whole book felt flat. Hamilton even alludes to herself being pressured to perform and get a book out every year, if you can read between the lines. I wonder if she's just burnt out, or if she simply had no idea of what to do with this series after the last book. It's been obvious for a while that she isn't edited nearly as much as she should be, and I wonder if anyone other than a sloppy proofreader even really read this before it was published. Whatever it was, this was far below par, even for her. The characters in this series deserved much better than this. Hell, we, her readers, deserved better than this. Both Hamilton and her publisher should be ashamed to charge readers good money for this.

So disappointing. The last 10% has a good plot line - shame the rest of the book is garbage. Again the author gets too involved in eye color, hair color, fashion and too-long sex scenes. I hoped for another book in the Merry Gentry series for a long time and was very disappointed in this total snooze-fest. It was like being trapped in the rambling mind of someone taking too many downers. I hope Ms Hamilton returns to her early, action-packed writing style with the next book.

Disappointing.  Little plot, lots and lots of descriptions of hair, eyes and clothing, as in every scene we get another VERY detailed description of the eyes, hair and clothing of characters we've seen many times before.  I found myself skimming these sections, while my mind wandered to logistical problems such as, who pulls all those 6 foot long rainbow colored hairs out of the shower drain, and just how long does it take any of these guys to style their hair for every scene?  I find the very, very long hair obsession LKH has to be a bit distracting.  I could let it ride when there was more action going on, but with nothing really happening except babies, my mind wanders into the practical aspects of this.  I suppose fairies could have magic to help them keep all that hair untangled, but what about the characters in the Anita Blake books?  How do they do it?  All that hair and clothes styling has got to take a large chunk of their day.  If I seem to be obsessing about the hair myself, it's because nothing much else really happens in this book until the very end(minor spoiler) when a major character is killed stupidly, and the main conflict is resolved(sort of) in a dream scene (almost identical to an earlier dream scene in this book), but THIS time it actually works.  Then it's all wrapped up neatly, but weirdly in an epilogue.  Just another thought, are deities usually mortal?  Seems like an oxymoron.

Wow!  I was so excited for this book.... utterly disappointed!!!! The major event taking place in the last few chapters still has me in shock,  but that was it, no climactic ending! Just a rushed wrap up, and no Sidhe justice for a major character.

Disappointing!  After waiting so long, it was very slow, many of the past stories were repeated and the story did not move anywhere.  I hope the next, if there is one, will be more interesting.  Or I will have to retire this series.

I won't bother rehashing what has already been said so I will get to the point: Laurell K. Hamilton,  if at some point you read through these, please understand how much most of us really loved this series, and that is why the way this book ended is so crushing. Don't buy this book!!! Save your $ its summer go buy an ice cream or ice coffee and go for a nice walk with someone you love. This book was a waste of my time and money! I will NEVER buy another book from LKH. EVER!!!

Cannot believe she killed off Sholto, one of the few actually interesting characters who she just made a love a marriage diety about five minutes before she killed him off. Kill off Frost who contributes nothing to the story besides pouting alot. Believe me we'd rather wait for a better book. What a disappointment.

I gave this book 3 stars, because I still love the characters. There was very little plot or character development. The bulk of the story was repetitive, Hamilton kept describing the men over and over again. The birth of the children was not really covered. The last 2 chapters covered a lot of ground, but most of it was "off-screen". Merry was not involved in most of the action. I was very disappointed and would love for Hamilton to go back to her original style of writing.

Not because of the length, but because of frustration with all of the cut and paste descriptions practically copied verbatim from previous books this series. How many times can an author describe what a red cap looks like? Just read this book to find out!  The last two chapters were great, if only the rest of the book was....  I'm sorry LKH, I love ya but this one bombed.

In the end, would say that it is not killing off King Sholto that disappointed me the most, but the feeling that the end of the story rushed to a tidy impotent conclusion. After the grand presentation of Merry to the Sluagh court as their queen, it felt like a disservice to Sholto's character to not give more page space for his death, the finding of his killers when in past stories the death of a kitchen brownie earned half book with of page time. There were parts of the story that felt finished, the birth of the children and scenes with Maeve as an example. The death of the Sluagh King came across as unfinished and an afterthought instead of just a shock of the length Teranus would go to to keep his kingdom. I feel the editors did a disservice to Hamilton on this book.

I honestly would give this zero stars if possible.  There is no editing to this book.  The conversations are like stream of consciousness as they ramble and repeat over and over again.  Nothing happens in this book, seriously, very little happens.  I am done with this series and probably this author.  I think she has forgotten how to write at this point

Too repetitive, some jumbling of information but still a good read. Ultimately it contained only a few events and didn't move the story far for the amount of pages it used. Disappointing but expected from this author.

As with the Anita Blake series Hamilton has lost her touch in this latest in the series I loved her first few books in this series.  Not much of a plot in this one just a lot of rambling about the Seelie and Unseelie courts, nd how hot her men re.

For someone who has read all the Merry Gentry books, this one is a let down. Way too much time spent on explaining the past, not nearly enough new material to warrant the price or the time reading it.

I have been a fan of LKH for years.  I've read everything she's written.  However lately I find the stories lacking, both Merry's and Anita's.  I don't know if Ms. Hamilton has lost touch with her characters or life has happened and she just isn't as into the writing as she once was, but the books have become flat, confused, contradictory, and somewhat boring. Seems rushed. Sad, as I've loved this series. Hoping for some more action and less descriptions of what the characters look like and what they say next time up!
I have been waiting for the continuation of Merry's story. This seemed lazy and, well, boring. The writing is heavy handed and laborious. very disappointing

I have to say that this book is no more than a collection of words packaged into paragraphs and from there to chapters. So painful to read! So much filler. I just finished the book and I'm not sure what the story was about. No one thing captures your attention or for that matter is continued throughout the book

I loved reading the Merry series UNTIL this book. What a horrible disappointment after such a long wait. Ms. Hamilton did not stay true to her characters, her writing, or Merry's past in this book. Sigh. We had to wait an eon for the latest Merry Gentry novel by Laurell K. Hamilton, but it was well-worth it! A Sliver of Light opens as Princess Merry has survived an abduction and rape by her Uncle (who’s proven to be a match for her Aunt, Queen of the Unseelie, Andais on the whacko scale), and her pregnancy is advanced as she waits with her lovers – men she loves, and the special ones she is IN love with. They are all anxious for the twins arrival as no one yet knows who the fathers are. But there are innumerable surprises in store, not least of which is Merry’s introduction to motherhood and the reactions of her cadre of guardians and lovers to the babes. But the horrors of the past have not been lain to rest. While she has given up her detective work due to her pregnancy (and she’s given up sex too, which ain’t easy when you’ve got a line of lovers extraordinaire up close and personal on a daily basis), the mysteries of faerie continue to keep her landscape shifting. The blessings of the Goddess, witnessed in showers of rose petals, have touched many in her life, including some of her guards, and her friend in fae, Maeve, a Hollywood queen. This uncertainty, coupled with the new mysteries, have everyone a bit off balance. Then the trouble really starts. Genetic testing to prove who the fathers are will also keep her violent and insane Uncle at bay, too. Because Merry was already pregnant when he raped her. So he couldn’t be the father. Could he? And her torture-loving Aunt Andais wants a home visit with the babies but everyone’s afraid she’ll lose control – it’s happened before and everyone knows they’ll rue the day it happens again. And while they wait to see the ongoing magickal developments in the babies – which might prove far more challenging than anyone would have thought – danger is getting closer. But who is their foe? As the men Merry loves are allowed back into her bed, there’s darkness close at hand. The police are trying to help. The paparazzi are desperate for pix of the first fairy babes born in America since Merry herself. And someone is closing in on Merry and her mixed band of warriors. When the battle comes, someone may not make it out alive. This is Hamilton at her very best. Supremely hot and sexy, sensual, dark and gritty, romantic, thrilling, and Sliver is a story filled with the love, compassion, loyalty and heartbreak that has been a staple in this masterfully constructed world of Princess Merry and the Seelie and Unseelie courts. If you’d despaired of more of Merry? The wait is over and you shall rejoice – as soon as you’ve grabbed a copy and locked yourself away. Because you’ll read this fast-paced paranormal in one sitting. Guaranteed.
